trans-unit.source: Signing a Driver for Public Release
trans-unit.target: Signing a Driver for Public Release

trans-unit.source: Before you release a driver package to the public, we recommend that you submit the package for certification.
trans-unit.target: Before you release a driver package to the public, we recommend that you submit the package for certification.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Windows Hardware Certification](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=248337) and [Hardware Dashboard Services](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=248336).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Windows Hardware Certification](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=248337) and [Hardware Dashboard Services](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=248336).

trans-unit.source: To submit a driver package for certification, you must sign the package with a certificate that you obtain from a trusted certification authority like VeriSign.
trans-unit.target: To submit a driver package for certification, you must sign the package with a certificate that you obtain from a trusted certification authority like VeriSign.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Get a VeriSign Certificate](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=248298).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Get a VeriSign Certificate](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=248298).

trans-unit.source: You will also need a cross certificate, which is provided by Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: You will also need a cross certificate, which is provided by Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: Suppose you have obtained a pair of files from Verisign: a private key file (PVK) and a software publishing certificate (SPC).
trans-unit.target: Suppose you have obtained a pair of files from Verisign: a private key file (PVK) and a software publishing certificate (SPC).

trans-unit.source: Also suppose you have a Microsoft Visual Studio solution that contains a driver project named MyDriver and a driver package project named MyDriver Package.
trans-unit.target: Also suppose you have a Microsoft Visual Studio solution that contains a driver project named MyDriver and a driver package project named MyDriver Package.

trans-unit.source: To sign your driver package, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: To sign your driver package, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: Use the [**Pvk2Pfx**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff550672) tool to create a Personal Information Exchange (PFX) certificate.
trans-unit.target: Use the [**Pvk2Pfx**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff550672) tool to create a Personal Information Exchange (PFX) certificate.

trans-unit.source: The **Pvk2Pfx** tool takes your PVK and SPC files as input and creates a single PFX file.
trans-unit.target: The **Pvk2Pfx** tool takes your PVK and SPC files as input and creates a single PFX file.

trans-unit.source: For this exercise, assume that your PFX file is named MyCert.pfx.
trans-unit.target: For this exercise, assume that your PFX file is named MyCert.pfx.

trans-unit.source: **Note** Once you have created your PFX file, you can reuse it for other driver projects and on other driver development computers.
trans-unit.target: **Note** Once you have created your PFX file, you can reuse it for other driver projects and on other driver development computers.

trans-unit.source: To determine which cross certificate you need, see [Cross-Certificates for Kernel Mode Code Signing](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=248296).
trans-unit.target: To determine which cross certificate you need, see [Cross-Certificates for Kernel Mode Code Signing](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=248296).

trans-unit.source: Verify that the required cross certificate is in $(BASEDIR)\\CrossCertificates, where $(BASEDIR) is the base directory of the Windows kits (for example c:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\8.0\\CrossCertificates).
trans-unit.target: Verify that the required cross certificate is in $(BASEDIR)\\CrossCertificates, where $(BASEDIR) is the base directory of the Windows kits (for example c:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\8.0\\CrossCertificates).

trans-unit.source: If the required cross certificate is not there, download the cross certificate from Microsoft, and copy it to $(BASEDIR)\\CrossCertificates.
trans-unit.target: If the required cross certificate is not there, download the cross certificate from Microsoft, and copy it to $(BASEDIR)\\CrossCertificates.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the solution that contains the MyDriver and MyDriver Package projects.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the solution that contains the MyDriver and MyDriver Package projects.

trans-unit.source: If the Solution Explorer window is not already open, choose **Solution Explorer** from the **View** menu.
trans-unit.target: If the Solution Explorer window is not already open, choose **Solution Explorer** from the **View** menu.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click the package project, **MyDriver Package**, and choose **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click the package project, **MyDriver Package**, and choose **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Signing > General**.
trans-unit.target: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Signing > General**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Sign Mode** drop-down list, select **Production Sign**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Sign Mode** drop-down list, select **Production Sign**.

trans-unit.source: For **Production Certificate**, do one of the following:
trans-unit.target: For **Production Certificate**, do one of the following:

trans-unit.source: Enter the path to your signing certificate (for example c:\\Certs\\MyCert.pfx).
trans-unit.target: Enter the path to your signing certificate (for example c:\\Certs\\MyCert.pfx).

trans-unit.source: Choose **Select From File**, and browse to your signing certificate.
trans-unit.target: Choose **Select From File**, and browse to your signing certificate.

trans-unit.source: Choose **Select From Store** and choose a certificate that you previously imported into a certificate store.
trans-unit.target: Choose **Select From Store** and choose a certificate that you previously imported into a certificate store.

trans-unit.source: **Note** To import a certificate into a store, right-click the certificate file (PFX file), and choose **Install PFX**.
trans-unit.target: **Note** To import a certificate into a store, right-click the certificate file (PFX file), and choose **Install PFX**.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions in the Certificate Import Wizard.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions in the Certificate Import Wizard.

trans-unit.source: **Note** If you decide to use a different certificate at a later time, be sure that your new certificate gets imported into the certificate store.
trans-unit.target: **Note** If you decide to use a different certificate at a later time, be sure that your new certificate gets imported into the certificate store.

trans-unit.source: If you choose **Select From File** and browse to your new certificate, the new certificate will be automatically imported into the certificate store.
trans-unit.target: If you choose **Select From File** and browse to your new certificate, the new certificate will be automatically imported into the certificate store.

trans-unit.source: However, if you manually enter the path to your new certificate, it will not be automatically imported into the certificate store.
trans-unit.target: However, if you manually enter the path to your new certificate, it will not be automatically imported into the certificate store.

trans-unit.source: In that case, you must right-click your new certificate file and choose **Install PFX**.
trans-unit.target: In that case, you must right-click your new certificate file and choose **Install PFX**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Driver Signing > General** property page, for **TimeStampServer**, select one of the time stamp servers in the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: On the **Driver Signing > General** property page, for **TimeStampServer**, select one of the time stamp servers in the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: **Note** Using one of the time stamp servers in the drop-down list requires that you be connected to the Internet when you build your driver package.
trans-unit.target: **Note** Using one of the time stamp servers in the drop-down list requires that you be connected to the Internet when you build your driver package.

trans-unit.source: If you need to be disconnected from the Internet when you build your driver package, clear the **TimeStampServer** field.
trans-unit.target: If you need to be disconnected from the Internet when you build your driver package, clear the **TimeStampServer** field.

trans-unit.source: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuration Properties > Inf2Cat > General**.
trans-unit.target: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuration Properties > Inf2Cat > General**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Run Inf2Cat** drop-down list, select **Yes**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Run Inf2Cat** drop-down list, select **Yes**.

trans-unit.source: Close the property pages for the package.
trans-unit.target: Close the property pages for the package.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the driver project, **MyDriver**, and choose **Properties**
trans-unit.target: Right-click the driver project, **MyDriver**, and choose **Properties**

trans-unit.source: In the property pages for the driver, navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Signing > General**.
trans-unit.target: In the property pages for the driver, navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Signing > General**.

trans-unit.source: Set **TimeStampServer** to the same value that you used in the driver package properties.
trans-unit.target: Set **TimeStampServer** to the same value that you used in the driver package properties.

trans-unit.source: Set **Sign Mode** to **Production Sign**, and set **Production Certificate** to the same value that you used in the driver package properties.
trans-unit.target: Set **Sign Mode** to **Production Sign**, and set **Production Certificate** to the same value that you used in the driver package properties.

trans-unit.source: When you are ready to build your driver package, press **F5**.
trans-unit.target: When you are ready to build your driver package, press **F5**.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio will automatically sign your package and your driver file.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio will automatically sign your package and your driver file.

trans-unit.source: If you have configured deployment, Visual Studio will also deploy your signed driver package to a test computer.
trans-unit.target: If you have configured deployment, Visual Studio will also deploy your signed driver package to a test computer.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Provision a computer for driver deployment and testing (WDK 8.1)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Dn745909).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Provision a computer for driver deployment and testing (WDK 8.1)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Dn745909).

trans-unit.source: Viewing the driver package files
trans-unit.target: Viewing the driver package files

trans-unit.source: After you build your solution, navigate in File Explorer to the folder that contains your driver package.
trans-unit.target: After you build your solution, navigate in File Explorer to the folder that contains your driver package.

trans-unit.source: One of the files in the package is a catalog file.
trans-unit.target: One of the files in the package is a catalog file.

trans-unit.source: The catalog file contains the digital signature for the package.
trans-unit.target: The catalog file contains the digital signature for the package.

trans-unit.source: For an example of viewing the files in a signed package, see [Writing a KMDF driver based on a template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).
trans-unit.target: For an example of viewing the files in a signed package, see [Writing a KMDF driver based on a template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).

trans-unit.source: Getting a WHQL release signature
trans-unit.target: Getting a WHQL release signature

trans-unit.source: When your driver package passes the certification tests, it can be signed by Windows Hardware Quality Labs (WHQL).
trans-unit.target: When your driver package passes the certification tests, it can be signed by Windows Hardware Quality Labs (WHQL).

trans-unit.source: If your driver package is signed by WHQL, it can be distributed through the Windows Update program or other Microsoft-supported distribution mechanisms.
trans-unit.target: If your driver package is signed by WHQL, it can be distributed through the Windows Update program or other Microsoft-supported distribution mechanisms.

trans-unit.source: Signing a package compared to signing an individual driver file
trans-unit.target: Signing a package compared to signing an individual driver file

trans-unit.source: A driver package contains several files.
trans-unit.target: A driver package contains several files.

trans-unit.source: Typically a driver package has one or more driver files, an information file (INF file), and a catalog file.
trans-unit.target: Typically a driver package has one or more driver files, an information file (INF file), and a catalog file.

trans-unit.source: The catalog file contains information about the other files in the package.
trans-unit.target: The catalog file contains information about the other files in the package.

trans-unit.source: When you sign the catalog file, the signature in the catalog file serves as the signature for the entire driver package.
trans-unit.target: When you sign the catalog file, the signature in the catalog file serves as the signature for the entire driver package.

trans-unit.source: In other words, *signing the catalog file* is the same as *signing the driver package*.
trans-unit.target: In other words, *signing the catalog file* is the same as *signing the driver package*.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, it is sufficient to sign the driver package, and it is not necessary to sign individual driver files.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, it is sufficient to sign the driver package, and it is not necessary to sign individual driver files.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, however, you need to sign both the package and the individual driver files.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, however, you need to sign both the package and the individual driver files.

trans-unit.source: For example, boot-start driver files must be individually signed.
trans-unit.target: For example, boot-start driver files must be individually signed.

trans-unit.source: Signing an individual driver file is referred to as *embedding a signature in the driver file*.
trans-unit.target: Signing an individual driver file is referred to as *embedding a signature in the driver file*.

trans-unit.source: Suppose you have a Visual Studio solution that contains a driver project named MyDriver and a driver package project named MyDriver Package.
trans-unit.target: Suppose you have a Visual Studio solution that contains a driver project named MyDriver and a driver package project named MyDriver Package.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio provides two sets of property pages: one for My Driver and one for My Driver Package.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio provides two sets of property pages: one for My Driver and one for My Driver Package.

trans-unit.source: To sign the driver package, set the **Driver Signing** properties of My Driver Package.
trans-unit.target: To sign the driver package, set the **Driver Signing** properties of My Driver Package.

trans-unit.source: To embed a signature in the individual driver file, set the **Driver Signing** properties of My Driver.
trans-unit.target: To embed a signature in the individual driver file, set the **Driver Signing** properties of My Driver.

trans-unit.source: When you set the driver package properties for production signing, remember to adjust the signing properties of the individual driver files accordingly.
trans-unit.target: When you set the driver package properties for production signing, remember to adjust the signing properties of the individual driver files accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Either turn off signing for the individual driver files, or set the individual driver files to use the same certificate that you specified for the package.
trans-unit.target: Either turn off signing for the individual driver files, or set the individual driver files to use the same certificate that you specified for the package.

trans-unit.source: Signing a driver package with two signatures
trans-unit.target: Signing a driver package with two signatures

trans-unit.source: In some cases, you might want to sign a driver package with two different signatures.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, you might want to sign a driver package with two different signatures.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose you want your driver to run on Windows Vista and Windows 7, 8, 8.1, and 10.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose you want your driver to run on Windows Vista and Windows 7, 8, 8.1, and 10.

trans-unit.source: Windows Vista supports only SHA1 signatures, but the later versions of Windows also support SHA2.
trans-unit.target: Windows Vista supports only SHA1 signatures, but the later versions of Windows also support SHA2.

trans-unit.source: ** Note ** SHA1 deprecation does not apply to drivers.
trans-unit.target: ** Note ** SHA1 deprecation does not apply to drivers.

trans-unit.source: For info about the end of SHA1 support in Windows, see [Windows Enforcement of Authenticode Code Signing and Timestamping](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/32288.windows-enforcement-of-authenticode-code-signing-and-timestamping.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For info about the end of SHA1 support in Windows, see [Windows Enforcement of Authenticode Code Signing and Timestamping](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/32288.windows-enforcement-of-authenticode-code-signing-and-timestamping.aspx).

trans-unit.source: You can sign your driver package with a primary signature that uses SHA1.
trans-unit.target: You can sign your driver package with a primary signature that uses SHA1.

trans-unit.source: Then you can append a secondary signature that uses SHA256.
trans-unit.target: Then you can append a secondary signature that uses SHA256.

trans-unit.source: You can use the same certificate for both signatures, or you can use separate certificates.
trans-unit.target: You can use the same certificate for both signatures, or you can use separate certificates.

trans-unit.source: Here are the steps to create the two signatures using Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Here are the steps to create the two signatures using Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click **Solution** *SolutionName*, and choose **Configuration Manager**.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click **Solution** *SolutionName*, and choose **Configuration Manager**.

trans-unit.source: For the driver project and the package project, set **Configuration** to **Win7 Release**, and set **Platform** to **x64**.
trans-unit.target: For the driver project and the package project, set **Configuration** to **Win7 Release**, and set **Platform** to **x64**.

trans-unit.source: Open the property pages for the driver package.
trans-unit.target: Open the property pages for the driver package.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Signing > General**.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Signing > General**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Sign Mode** drop-down list, select **Production Sign**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Sign Mode** drop-down list, select **Production Sign**.

trans-unit.source: For **Production Certificate**, enter the path to your signing certificate.
trans-unit.target: For **Production Certificate**, enter the path to your signing certificate.

trans-unit.source: In the property pages for the driver package, navigate to **Configuration Properties > Custom Build Step > General**.
trans-unit.target: In the property pages for the driver package, navigate to **Configuration Properties > Custom Build Step > General**.

trans-unit.source: For **Description**, select **Performing Custom Build Step**.
trans-unit.target: For **Description**, select **Performing Custom Build Step**.

trans-unit.source: For **Execute After**, select **DriverProductionSign**.
trans-unit.target: For **Execute After**, select **DriverProductionSign**.

trans-unit.source: For **Command Line**, enter this command.
trans-unit.target: For **Command Line**, enter this command.

trans-unit.source: **Signtool sign /fd sha256 /ph /as /sha1** *XX...XX* **$(TargetPath)**
trans-unit.target: **Signtool sign /fd sha256 /ph /as /sha1** *XX...XX* **$(TargetPath)**

trans-unit.source: where *XX...XX* is the hash of the certificate you are using for the the secondary signature.
trans-unit.target: where *XX...XX* is the hash of the certificate you are using for the the secondary signature.

trans-unit.source: **Note** To see the hash (also called the thumb print) of a certificate, open a Command Prompt window and navigate to the directory that contains your certificate.
trans-unit.target: **Note** To see the hash (also called the thumb print) of a certificate, open a Command Prompt window and navigate to the directory that contains your certificate.

trans-unit.source: Enter the command **certutil -dump** *CertName.pfx*, where *CertName.pfx* is the name of your certificate.
trans-unit.target: Enter the command **certutil -dump** *CertName.pfx*, where *CertName.pfx* is the name of your certificate.
